title: Treasury holds up payment to charter schools amid stalemate
text:
HARRISBURG, Pa. (AP) - The Pennsylvania Treasury Department says it won't make any payments to charter schools using dollars that are normally sent directly to public school districts.
Treasury spokesman Scott Sloat said Wednesday that the agency wants to review the legality of the diversions. Also Wednesday, the Pennsylvania School Boards Association sued to ensure the money is sent to school districts, insisting that it's illegal to divert the cash to charter schools.
The dispute comes amid a four-month-old stalemate that's held up billions in state aid to public schools.
Gov. Tom Wolf's administration says state law requires the diversions since some school districts have cut off monthly payments to charter schools. A spokesman says the administration is still determining the appropriate amounts to divert.
The money comes from a tax on slot-machine gambling.
